questions.question_text:
Text 1

Public libraries have evolved beyond lending books. Many now offer free internet access, homework help, and workshops. Supporters argue that libraries remain vital community hubs, especially for people who lack reliable internet at home.

Text 2

Online databases and open-access materials have made information easier to find, but not everyone knows how to evaluate sources or navigate paywalls. Librarians can guide patrons to credible resources and teach research skills that improve information literacy.

Based on the texts, both authors would most likely agree with which statement?

Text 1

A neighborhood study found that adding protected bike lanes reduced crash rates for cyclists and encouraged more people to ride. The authors conclude that building more protected lanes is the best way to make streets safer.

Text 2

Some residents worry that new bike lanes remove parking and change traffic patterns. Still, they acknowledge that protected lanes can improve safety. They argue that any expansion should consider local needs, loading zones, and complementary traffic-calming measures.

Based on the texts, how would the author of Text 2 most likely respond to the claim in Text 1 that building more protected bike lanes is the best way to make streets safer?

Text 1

Online courses allow students to learn at their own pace and fit education into busy schedules. This flexibility can help working adults and people in rural areas access classes that might not be available locally.

Text 2

In-person classes offer spontaneous discussions and social interaction that can deepen understanding. Even so, many learners benefit from online options when commuting or fixed class times would otherwise prevent them from enrolling.

Based on the texts, both authors would most likely agree with which statement?

Text 1

Planting more street trees can reduce heat, improve air quality, and make neighborhoods more pleasant. The city should prioritize planting as many trees as possible in all districts.

Text 2

A budget officer notes that trees require ongoing care such as pruning and watering. While agreeing that trees provide environmental benefits, the officer recommends focusing on heat hot spots and ensuring maintenance funds are in place before large-scale planting.

Based on the texts, how would the author of Text 2 most likely respond to the emphasis in Text 1 on planting as many trees as possible across the city?

Text 1

An engineering team has launched a device that collects floating plastic from ocean currents. Early tests show promising removal rates, leading the team to argue that large-scale cleanup can meaningfully reduce ocean pollution.

Text 2

A marine scientist agrees cleanup helps but stresses that plastic often enters the ocean from rivers and poorly managed waste. Preventing new plastic from reaching the water is critical; otherwise, cleanup efforts will always be chasing an ongoing problem.

Based on the texts, both authors would most likely agree with which statement?

Text 1

A local editor argues that a printed weekly newspaper keeps residents informed about school board decisions, road closures, and community events. Print, the editor says, encourages slower, more thorough reading.

Text 2

A civic group publishes a daily email bulletin with brief updates and links for details. They contend that digital formats deliver timely information, though readers may skim. They believe consistent, clear updates matter more than the medium.

Based on the texts, how would the author of Text 2 most likely respond to Text 1's suggestion that a printed newspaper is necessary to keep residents informed?

Text 1

Advocates of space tourism argue that early, expensive flights will drive innovation, eventually lowering costs and opening space experiences to more people.

Text 2

An environmental ethicist cautions that rocket launches have ecological impacts and currently serve a very small, wealthy group. Still, the ethicist concedes that new technologies can spread beyond initial luxury markets over time.

Based on the texts, both authors would most likely agree with which statement?

Text 1

Plant-based meat alternatives can reduce demand for animal farming and lower environmental impacts. Many consumers find these products appealing because they are familiar in taste and convenient to cook.

Text 2

A nutritionist notes that some plant-based meats are highly processed and can be high in sodium. While supportive of reducing meat consumption, the nutritionist recommends checking labels and building meals around whole foods like beans, vegetables, and grains.

Based on the texts, how would the author of Text 2 most likely characterize the optimism in Text 1 about plant-based meat alternatives?

Text 1

Virtual museum tours allow people to explore collections from anywhere. They can preview exhibits, read labels, and see high-resolution images that are otherwise difficult to access.

Text 2

A curator values in-person visits for scale, texture, and the atmosphere of a gallery. Even so, the curator views virtual tours as valuable outreach that helps schools and distant visitors engage with art.

Based on the texts, both authors would most likely agree with which statement?

Text 1

An arts educator argues that after-school music and theater programs improve creativity, school attendance, and confidence. The educator urges districts to make arts funding a top priority.

Text 2

A budget analyst agrees that arts programs benefit students but notes that districts face constraints such as staffing, transportation, and facility costs. The analyst recommends partnerships and targeted grants to support arts alongside other essential programs.

Based on the texts, how would the author of Text 2 most likely respond to Text 1's argument that arts programs should receive top funding priority in all schools?

options.label: Libraries remain valuable community resources even as online information grows.
Digital resources have made public libraries largely obsolete.
Online databases are less reliable than printed encyclopedias.
Community programs at libraries should be replaced by virtual events only.
By disagreeing and claiming protected bike lanes do not affect safety.
By agreeing about safety benefits but emphasizing careful planning to address parking and traffic trade-offs.
By claiming that protected lanes automatically increase local retail sales.
By asserting that only driver education, not infrastructure, improves safety.
In-person classes are obsolete and should be phased out.
Online courses are inferior for all students and should be avoided.
Online learning can expand access for those who cannot attend campus regularly.
Group discussion is less important than meeting assignment deadlines.
By insisting that trees have no measurable effect on urban heat.
By proposing to remove existing trees to save maintenance funds.
By agreeing and calling for immediate citywide planting without a maintenance plan.
By acknowledging the benefits but advocating for targeted planting with dedicated maintenance funding.
Preventing plastic from entering the ocean is essential for long-term improvement.
Cleanup devices alone can permanently solve marine pollution.
Plastic waste is largely harmless to marine life and ecosystems.
Source reduction is unnecessary if cleanup operations are frequent.
By agreeing entirely that print is the only effective medium for informing residents.
By arguing that digital newsletters can keep residents informed effectively, though reading habits differ.
By claiming that neither print nor digital formats can inform residents well.
By stating that information should be shared only at in-person town meetings.
Space tourism currently has minimal environmental impact and should be expanded rapidly.
Governments should ban private spaceflight to prevent luxury travel.
Present-day space tourism is costly and accessible to very few people.
Commercial space travel will replace air travel for most trips within a decade.
As fully justified because processed foods are always nutritionally superior.
As misguided since the environmental impacts of food production are negligible.
As accurate only if consumers completely avoid vegetables and whole grains.
As reasonable regarding environmental aims but in need of caution about processing and balanced diets.
Virtual tours help people who cannot travel access collections.
In-person visits are unnecessary in the era of high-resolution images.
Museums should stop funding digital projects and invest only in galleries.
Online tours fully replace the sensory experience of a gallery.
By fully agreeing that arts should always be funded above all other programs.
By acknowledging the benefits of arts but arguing that funding decisions must balance multiple needs and constraints.
By claiming that arts programs have no measurable benefits for students.
By suggesting that eliminating arts programs would simplify school budgets.
